lines.text: An unhappy alternative is before you, Elizabeth. Your mother will never see you again if you do not marry Mr. Collins. And I will never see you again if you do.
Look at them! Five of them without dowries. What's to become of them?
Yes, what's to become of the wretched creatures? Perhaps we should have drowned some of them at birth.
...and her sisters Jane and Elizabeth were seen running down Market Street in an attempt to escape their disgrace. Isn't that exquisitely funny, Mr. Darcy?
Exquisitely. Just think how you would roar with laughter if it happened to yourself.
Has anybody heard how Jane is this morning?
Eh, Mr. Bingley sent a note over by his groom. She's much better. Such a happy idea of mine sending her off in the rain.
Yes, but to Jane must go all the credit for having caught the cold, my dear.
Yes, she looks tolerable enough, but I am in no humor tonight to give consequence to the middle classes at play.
Oh, if you want to be really refined, you have to be dead. There's no one as dignified as a mummy
Mary, try to sparkle a little.
[Mary grins horribly]
Just a little!
I have made the mistake of being honest with you.
Honesty is a greatly overrated virtue. Silence in this case would have been more agreeable.
You must allow me to tell you how much I admire and love you.

Well, we're hoping Elizabeth can manage to catch a cold of her own and stay long enough to get engaged to Mr. Darcy. Then, if a good snowstorm could be arranged, we'd send Kitty over. But if a young man should happen to be in the house - a young man who likes singing, of course, who can discuss philosophy - Mary could go. Then, if a dashing young soldier in a handsome uniform should appear for Lydia, everything would be perfect, my dear.

[observing the Bennet family at the party at Netherfield]
Entertaining the rustics is not as difficult as I feared. Any simple, childish game seems to amuse them excessively.
Oh Mr. Darcy, Miss Bingley here is eager for her lesson. I hope you will enjoy it, Miss Bingley, and that you will learn to direct your darts with greater accuracy.
How clever of you, Miss Bingley, to know something of which you are ignorant.
Did you tell him you had five daughters, Papa?
Well, I told him if he ran into five of the silliest girls in England, they would be my daughters!

I rather admired what you did this afternoon Miss Elizabeth. Your resentment of what you believe to be an injustice showed courage and loyalty. I could wish i might possess a friend who would defend me as ably as Mr. Wickham was defended today.
At this moment it's difficult to believe that you're so proud.
At this moment it's difficult to believe that you're so prejudiced.
You must learn, Mrs. Collins, to draw a firm line between the deserving poor and the undeserving.
I tremble and obey.
Well, ignorance is bliss!
